para.paratext: Identity of a person is always a proper subject for opinion testimony.[1] A witness may base his opinion regarding the identity of an individual on appearance, size, tone of voice, and any mark of peculiarity of the person identified.[2] If a witness cannot positively identify an individual, his opinion and best judgment are admissible.[3]

A lay witness who is neither a witness to nor a victim of a crime but who has viewed a surveillance videotape of the commission of a crime is permitted to give his opinion of the identity of a person depicted on the videotape.[4] However, there must be “some basis for concluding that the witness is more likely to correctly identify the defendant from the photograph than is the jury.”[5] This requirement is met if “the witness is familiar with the defendant's appearance around the time the surveillance photograph was taken and the defendant's appearance has changed prior to trial.”[6]

Testimony of experts on the reasons why teenage prostitutes do not run away from their pimps, prostitution terminology, and scare tactics frequently used by pimps upon prostitutes has been allowed. In this case, the court reasoned that these matters were beyond the ken of the average juror and helped identify the defendant.[7]

The law disallows expert testimony regarding inaccuracies in eyewitness identification.[8] In Henderson v. State,[9] the Georgia Court of Appeals upheld the exclusion of opinion testimony from a substance abuse counselor regarding the effect of crack cocaine on a person's perception and memory. The defendant sought to introduce this testimony because the victim and her brother, who had purchased cocaine several hours before the assault, identified the defendant.
Garrett v. State, 141 Ga. App. 584, 234 S.E.2d 161 (1977); Redd v. State, 141 Ga. App. 888, 234 S.E.2d 812 (1977).
In Henry v. State, 178 Ga. App. 127, 342 S.E.2d 499 (1986), identification of the defendant by a witness was based on a vocal exemplar and voice in a lineup.

See also Stevanus v. State, 185 Ga. App. 7, 363 S.E.2d 322 (1987); Lowe v. State, 185 Ga. App. 606, 365 S.E.2d 479 (1988); Martin v. State, 193 Ga. App. 581, 388 S.E.2d 420 (1989); Reid v. State, 210 Ga. App. 783, 437 S.E.2d 646 (1993).

Pretrial photographic lineup was not impermissibly suggestive merely because six photos were used for robbery involving three suspects, where the detective had told victims that suspects were in custody and that their pictures would appear in the lineup. Since the lay witness' opinion that the remains were undoubtedly those of his father was not based on factors peculiar to the remains, the admission of his opinion was inappropriate. Quedens v. State, 280 Ga. 355, 629 S.E.2d 197 (2006).
Bray v. State, 26 Ga. App. 620, 106 S.E. 800 (1921); Randall v. State, 73 Ga. App. 354, 36 S.E.2d 450 (1945).
Strickland v. State, 302 Ga. App. 44, 690 S.E.2d 638 (2010).

App. 668, 440 S.E.2d 256 (1994) (trial court did not err in refusing defendant's request to permit expert testimony on potential inaccuracies in eyewitness identification; witness's credibility as to the identification is within the exclusive province of the jury).
